cases.title: FAST - Negative Exam
key_features: No anechoic (black) free fluid in Morrison's pouch
cases.clinical_context: Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma. Used in trauma to rapidly detect free intraperitoneal or pericardial fluid
cases.management: Negative FAST does not rule out injury. Unstable patient needs laparotomy. Stable patient may need CT

cases.title: FAST - Positive (Free Fluid in Morrison's)
key_features: Anechoic (black) stripe between liver and kidney
Free fluid in Morrison's pouch (hepatorenal recess)
May see fluid in other quadrants
cases.clinical_context: TRAUMA ALERT. Free intraperitoneal fluid in trauma = blood until proven otherwise. Morrison's pouch is most dependent area in supine position
cases.management: Unstable + positive FAST → immediate laparotomy. Stable → may proceed to CT for source identification

cases.title: Lung - A-Lines (Normal)
cases.clinical_context: Normal lung ultrasound. Air-filled alveoli create reverberation artifacts (A-lines). Lung sliding indicates visceral pleura moving against parietal pleura

cases.title: Lung - B-Lines (Pulmonary Edema)
key_features: Vertical laser-like artifacts from pleural line
Extend to bottom of screen without fading
cases.clinical_context: B-lines = thickened interlobular septa from fluid/inflammation. Bilateral B-lines suggest cardiogenic pulmonary edema, ARDS, or interstitial pneumonia
cases.management: Acute heart failure: diuretics, vasodilators, BiPAP. ARDS: mechanical ventilation, lung-protective strategy

cases.title: Pneumothorax (Absent Lung Sliding)
key_features: Lung point (junction of pneumothorax and normal lung)
cases.clinical_context: Air in pleural space prevents visceral pleura from sliding against parietal pleura. Sensitivity >90% for ruling out pneumothorax
views: Anterior chest (most sensitive position in supine patient)
cases.management: Small stable: observation + O2. Large/symptomatic: needle decompression or chest tube. Tension PTX: immediate needle decompression

cases.title: Pleural Effusion
key_features: Spine sign (vertebral bodies visible through fluid)
cases.clinical_context: Fluid in pleural space. Causes: heart failure, pneumonia (parapneumonic), malignancy, cirrhosis, PE, nephrotic syndrome
views: Posterior chest (patient sitting or lateral decubitus)
cases.management: Diagnostic thoracentesis (Light's criteria). Therapeutic drainage if large. Treat underlying cause

cases.title: Cardiac - Normal 4-Chamber View
key_features: Four chambers visible (LA, RA, LV, RV)
cases.clinical_context: Apical 4-chamber view. Best for assessing LV function, chamber sizes, and pericardial effusion

cases.title: Pericardial Effusion with Tamponade
key_features: Right ventricular collapse in early diastole
cases.clinical_context: LIFE-THREATENING. Beck's triad: hypotension, JVD, muffled heart sounds. Causes: malignancy, uremia, post-MI (Dressler's), aortic dissection, trauma
cases.management: URGENT pericardiocentesis. Volume resuscitation as bridge. Avoid positive pressure ventilation

cases.title: Severe LV Dysfunction
cases.clinical_context: Cardiogenic shock. Causes: acute MI, chronic ischemic cardiomyopathy, dilated cardiomyopathy, myocarditis, severe AS/MR
cases.management: Inotropes (dobutamine), diuretics, vasodilators. Mechanical support (IABP, Impella) if refractory. PCI if STEMI

cases.title: Massive Pulmonary Embolism (RV Strain)
cases.clinical_context: Acute RV pressure overload from massive PE. Hemodynamically unstable. High mortality. Wells score, troponin, BNP elevated
cases.management: EMERGENCY. Thrombolysis if unstable. Anticoagulation (heparin). ECMO or surgical embolectomy if refractory

cases.title: DVT - Positive Compression Test
key_features: Absent or reduced flow on Doppler
cases.clinical_context: Lower extremity DVT. 2-point compression US (CFV and popliteal) has 95% sensitivity for proximal DVT. Wells score guides testing
cases.management: Anticoagulation (DOAC or LMWH→warfarin). Provoked vs unprovoked determines duration (3 months vs indefinite)

cases.title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)
cases.clinical_context: AAA defined as aortic diameter >3 cm. Risk of rupture increases with size (>5.5cm). Screening in men >65 who ever smoked
cases.management: <5.5cm: surveillance. >5.5cm or symptomatic: surgical repair (open or EVAR). Ruptured: EMERGENCY surgery

cases.title: IVC - Plethoric (Volume Overload)
cases.clinical_context: Plethoric IVC suggests elevated right atrial pressure. Causes: heart failure, pericardial tamponade, pulmonary hypertension, tricuspid regurgitation
cases.management: Diuretics if heart failure. Treat underlying cause

cases.title: IVC - Collapsed (Hypovolemia)
cases.clinical_context: Collapsed IVC suggests hypovolemia or low right atrial pressure. Causes: hemorrhage, dehydration, sepsis with vasodilation
cases.management: Fluid resuscitation (crystalloid or blood). Find and treat source of volume loss

cases.title: Hydronephrosis - Moderate
cases.clinical_context: Obstruction of urinary collecting system. Causes: stone, stricture, mass, pregnancy, BPH, retroperitoneal fibrosis
cases.management: Mild: observation. Moderate/severe + infection = EMERGENCY (nephrostomy/ureteral stent). CT for stone protocol
